text.p: The following is a direct contribution from commodity statistician F.O. Licht in Ratzeburg, Germany. Please address any queries to Helmut Ahlfeld on +00 49 4541 88920.

White sugar futures in London ended mixed with nearby positions holding at or near their day's peaks on steady New York raws. But movements on both spreads and premiums remained tight before New York's March raws expiry. Spot May finished just 10 cents up at $306.20 a tonne after a high of $306.50. Earlier trade and broker selling drove the spot contract down to a low of $304. May/August hovered between premium and discount as May weakened in a continued technical reaction to last week's strength.

Raw sugar futures in New York settled near the day's highs, buoyed by late-session speculative buying and interest from Far Eastern dealers in the March/May spread, floor sources said. The most active May contract closed 0.06 cents higher at 10.89 cents, having ranged from 10.75 to 10.91 cents. The spot March contract settled up 0.10 cents to 10.90 cents. Traders said the market will turn its attention from the spread to the May contract, pegging nearby resistance at just over today's high, at 10.92 cents. Support was seen at 10.72 cents in May.

MEXICO - The Mexican Sugar Chamber, the umbrella organization for sugar mills, recently revised its crop estimate for the 1996/97 campaign up to 4.745 million tonnes, raw value, up from 4.740 million tonnes estimated earlier. 1995/96 sugar production amounted to a record high of 4.758 million tonnes. Production up to February 25 was 1.912 million tonnes, of which refined sugar 725,298 tonnes and standard white sugar 1.120 million tonnes. Brown sugar totalled 25,014 tonnes and special white output had reached 41,646 tonnes. The chamber said 59 of the country's 62 active mills were currently working.

JAMAICA - Sugar production in July 1996 amounted to 10,700 tonnes, raw value, compared to last year's 11,041 tonnes. This brought cumulative production in the first three quarters of 1995/96 (November/July) up to 236,735 tonnes against 208,444 tonnes in 1994/95. Total output in 1994/95 reached 211,539 tonnes compared to 220,350 tonnes in 1993/94. Jamaica expects to produce a total of 256,000 tonnes of sugar in 1997 and exports are expected to reach 175,000 tonnes, nearly all of which will go to the European Union under the ACP arrangements. Jamaica has a total production capacity of 350,000 tonnes per year.

GERMANY - Sugar imports in October 1996, the first month of the 1996/97 campaign, amounted to 27,937 tonnes, raw value, up from last year's 20,335 tonnes. Total imports in 1995/96 reached 206,911 tonnes compared to 225,848 tonnes in 1994/95. The major country of origin in October 1996 was France with 20,264 tonnes whites against 15,830 tonnes. Sugar exports in October 1996 amounted to 173,610 tonnes, raw value, up from 139,459 tonnes exported in October 1995. Total exports in 1995/96 reached 1.316 million tonnes compared to 1.452 million tonnes in 1994/95 and 1.922 million tonnes in 1993/94.

Major countries of destination in October 1996 were Belgium- Luxembourg with 37,496 tonnes whites against 25,655 tonnes, Italy with 23,650 tonnes, up from 8,128 tonnes, the United Arab Emirates with 12,535 tonnes, down from 16,510 tonnes and Tunisia with 14,210 tonnes against nil.

The European Union awarded 30,300 tonnes of white sugar at a maximum refund of ECU 44.471 per 100 kg at its weekly tender on Wednesday. Cumulative awards so far made under the 1996/97 series of tenders for the period up to February 26 reached 1,563,150 tonnes, which compares to 1,601,198 tonnes last year. Syria tendered to buy 13,000 tonnes of whites and 13,000 tonnes of raws, both for April shipment. Iraq has postponed its tender to buy sugar under the UN oil-for-food deal until February 28, European traders said.
